title: Elderly pet greyhound savaged to death by alligator after escaping her yard
text:
Eric Smith said his dog was attacked and killed by an alligator that reportedly broke his dogs neck and jaw. (Picture: Eric Smith/ File photo)

A pet owner has was left heartbroken after an alligator mauled his much-loved dog to death.

Eric Smith, 55, told Metro US that his 15-year-old Italian greyhound Abby was killed by the cold-blooded reptile last week in Big Pine Key, Florida.

Smith, who lives with husband Aaron Stultz, 44, said he was home from work and let his dogs out in his backyard, but Abby disappeared through a hole she found in the couple’s fence.

He searched for Abby for three hours – only to find her body in floating a canal two lots away from his house with the alligator believed to have killed her lurking nearby.

Smith said: ‘It looked like (the alligator) broke her neck, broke her jaw and like really gouged her neck. You know, her jugular vein was bleeding when I found her.’

Smith said the fatal alligator attack on Abby (left) has left him terrified to let his other dogs out in his backyard. (Picture: Eric Smith)

‘I think, initially, she was done in two seconds,’ he continued, adding that the alligator swam off when he arrived, but stayed in the area.

Smith called the Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission (FWC), and he removed Abby’s corpse from the canal before the alligator returned to the body to do any further damage. Animal officials later arrived to trap and remove the alligator.

‘Immediately I knew… there was no chance I’m taking her to the vet, to help her and revive her. But at the same moment, the (alligator) was there and he dipped under the water and swam off. I don’t know, it was an indescribable feeling,’ he said.

‘It was a little bit of shock, disbelief, and also relief.’ Smith explained that it would have been worse if the gator had taken Abby to eat her and left him wondering if she was still alive but lost and hungry.

He continued: ‘All I wanted to do was find her and understand what happened…It’s always not knowing that’s the worst.’

Smith said he hopes to raise awareness about alligators in the canal near his home. (Picture: Google Maps)

‘I found my dog at a place where the alligator took her to stash her for a while…I truly believe I found my dog before (the alligator) had a chance to find her, before he came back to eat her,’ Smith continued.

Smith shared news of Abby’s death this week in the hope of warning others of the potential threat posed by alligators in Big Pine Key.

‘I have family come down here on vacation…and their kids are jumping into the canal and swimming an this and that. You know, an awareness would be prudent,’ he said.

‘And if there are problem gators, then a community effort would help to identify where they are so (animal control) can come down and grab them.’

Smith said he has other dogs and Abby’s death has left him afraid to let them out into his backyard.

‘Right now, we’re in fear everyday…our next stop is to put a fencing along the sea wall so our dogs can’t get close to the canal system.’

Alligators are currently categorized as threatened species in the Florida Keys. Killing them is illegal and hunting or trapping them requires a permit and adherence to a strictly enforced quota, according to the Key West Aquarium.
